entry.title: An Introduction to CSS Logical Properties

content.p: For years, we‚Äôve identified CSS locations with physical keywords: top, right, bottom, and left. These words are tied to the physical dimensions of the browser viewport itself. Any property containing the word left is connected to the left edge of the browser window. Many properties use this physical location syntax (margin, padding, border, and the position-related properties).

We‚Äôve been writing CSS like this for so many years, it‚Äôs hard to imagine changing the way we think about identifying locations. However, there‚Äôs a new evolution in the way we identify locations and directions in CSS, and it allows us to create much more robust layouts with less code! Let‚Äôs take a look at logical properties.

Logical properties respond automatically to text direction and writing mode. This means that locations formerly identified by left and right will automatically reverse for RTL layouts, and horizontal and vertical properties will automatically rotate for vertical writing mode.

If you‚Äôre not familiar with ‚ÄúLTR‚Äù (left-to-right) and ‚ÄúRTL‚Äù (right-to-left) or vertical writing mode, I recommend reading Jen Simmons‚Äô post on writing modes or watching her writing modes video.
The new keywords block and inline describe vertical and horizontal axes. To remember how these properties work, I like to picture a long paragraph of text.

The block axis runs from the start to the end of the block of text. For languages with horizontal text direction (including both LTR and RTL), that‚Äôs the axis that runs from the top to the bottom of the paragraph. For languages with vertical writing mode, the block axis still runs from the start to the end of each block of text. Because these languages present text in vertical columns, however, the block axis automatically adapts and runs horizontally.

The inline axis runs from the start to the end of a line of text in the paragraph. For LTR and RTL languages, that‚Äôs horizontal. Just like before, when you use inline properties in a vertical writing mode, the inline axis adapts and runs vertically.
Another way to describe these new axes is:

ul.li: block = perpendicular to a line of text
inline = parallel to a line of text

content.p: Now that we can use block and inline to identify vertical and horizontal dimensions in a way that adapts to writing mode, we can add start and end to identify which end of the axis we need to target.
Let‚Äôs get our bearings by looking at the old familiar physical properties
Now, how do logical properties compare to current physical properties in LTR writing mode?

img.alt: Logical Properties in LTR Writing Mode

content.p: Now, watch how these properties respond to a change in localization. If our site is translated into Arabic or Hebrew, the dir="rtl" attribute will cause this change in the inline locations:

img.alt: Logical Properties in RTL Writing Mode

content.p: RTL is cool, but let‚Äôs check out the vertical text. Han-based languages (sometimes identified as CJK: Chinese, Japanese, Korean) can run vertically from right to left. If we were building a web app that would be localized for users reading these languages, we could support that writing mode by adding writing-mode: vertical-rl to the root element. Then our logical properties would adapt to match the rotated block and inline axes:

img.alt: Logical Properties in Vertical RL Writing Mode

content.p: All the physical properties I mentioned above can be replaced with logical properties: margin, padding, and border properties can be replaced with logical suffixes. Positioning properties like top are replaced by inset-block-start. You can even use float and clear with logical values: inline-start and inline-end.
Let‚Äôs take a look at some examples of logical properties in real life!
Here are a few lists of logical properties and values:
content.h4: Properties & Values that You Might Not Have Realized Are Logical
content.p: In Flexbox and Grid, justify-* and align-* use logical values.
content.h4: Logical Properties with Solid Modern Browser Support
Logical Properties & Values with only Firefox Support
content.p: Breaking these properties down helps us decide which to use.

ul.li: Seeing Flexbox and Grid as logical property systems help us get our minds around the concepts.
The properties that are widely supported are worth exploring now (if you don‚Äôt support IE11).
The properties and values that are Firefox-only are good to know about, but not ready for production use, in my opinion.

content.p: To begin, here‚Äôs an example of logical properties at work in some code that may feel familiar to many front-end devs.

content.p: We‚Äôve created a simple job posting card layout with CSS Grid. The column containing the title and department will take up as much room as is available, and the column with the location and hours will be only as wide as it needs to be. We‚Äôll need to align both the location and hours to the end of their column.

Let‚Äôs find the logical properties here. First, in justify-content - the grid columns will all be shifted to the start of the inline axis. In LTR, they‚Äôll be at the left; in RTL, they‚Äôll be at the right. Second, we‚Äôre overriding that start value for the location and hours. We always want that text to be aligned to the end of the grid, so we justify it with end. In the past, you might‚Äôve just put text-align: right on that element (and then needed more CSS to override that in RTL mode). However, using Grid with justify-self: end, we get the same visual effect and it automatically switches for non-LTR writing modes.
And yes, text-align: end would produce the same effect as justify-self: end in this context.

I recently worked on a project with horizontally-scrollable rows. Each row had scroll-left / scroll-right buttons absolutely positioned at the left and right edges. The row used Grid layout, so as soon as we went RTL, it flipped automatically, but the buttons stayed put. Let‚Äôs use logical properties to solve that problem.
Using left and right would have caused RTL problems, but using inset-inline-* creates positioning that responds correctly to changes in writing mode.
You can use logical properties to make sure floated images are positioned correctly as well. With the existing physical properties, it was common to float images like this:
But now, with logical properties, we can make that more resilient:

Logical properties appear to have remarkably good browser support. According to caniuse, logical property support is as good as Grid support: all major desktop browsers, Mobile Safari, and modern Android browsers.
However, that‚Äôs not the end of the story. I wish it were. It‚Äôd be great if logical properties worked as well as caniuse indicates!
First, a number of the properties I showed above are only supported by Firefox at the time of writing:

This means ‚Äúnon-supporting browsers‚Äù is a pretty large category. You still support some browsers that are at least partially non-supporting, even if you‚Äôve dropped IE11. In this case, you could start writing logical properties now and use a PostCSS plugin called postcss-logical-properties to back-fill the old physical values. However, it‚Äôs worth noting that that plugin only supports LTR/RTL, not any vertical writing modes.

Without using that PostCSS plugin (which I haven‚Äôt tried out on any significant projects, so your mileage may vary), fallback CSS is a bit tricky. The fallback CSS requires an additional attribute selector ([dir="rtl"]) and that raises your specificity. That higher specificity now overrides your logical property code, even in modern browsers. In the code example below, the 2nd block overrides the 3rd even in supporting browsers, making the logical property effectively worthless. (@supports and @media queries don‚Äôt increase specificity.)
If all your supported browsers support @supports, you could do use both positive and negative @supports queries. Note: IE11 doesn‚Äôt support @supports so this won‚Äôt work there.
However, that‚Äôs a lot of code. In fact, you could delete almost half (6 of those 13 lines) and nothing would change. üòø

Unlike CSS Grid and some other areas where new CSS allows entirely new behavior, there‚Äôs no visible difference for users if you use logical properties with fallbacks. There are extra lines of code, I‚Äôm afraid.

As a rule, I don‚Äôt subscribe to the idea that ‚Äúwe shouldn‚Äôt use new CSS if we still need to write fallback styles.‚Äù However, in this case, writing logical properties with physical property fallbacks has significant specificity complications (which aren‚Äôt an issue with Grid). Additionally, the presence of merely partial support in Chrome and Safari makes fallbacks entirely necessary. Here‚Äôs a very detailed explanation of current shortcomings with logical properties.
At this point, my recommendation for implementing logical properties is cautious:

ul.li: Only use properties and values that work in all your supported browsers.
If you need to include fallback CSS in the same stylesheet, just use the fallback. Save logical properties for later.
If you need to support older browsers but you‚Äôre itching to use logical properties, use logical properties with a PostCSS plugin that converts them to physical properties.

If your project uses code-splitting in a way that allows different CSS delivery methods that match browser support for logical properties, use logical properties in the CSS that‚Äôs delivered to supporting browsers and use physical properties in the CSS that‚Äôs sent to non-supporting browsers.

content.p: Even if your current projects and requirements don‚Äôt allow you to use logical properties in all the ways mentioned here, don‚Äôt lose heart! Support will continue to grow and browser support baselines will improve. Knowing this syntax will set up well to write better CSS in the near future.

A bunch of other publishers & newsletters picked up on this too (CSS-Tricks, Smashing Magazine, CSS Weekly, and Calibre, to name a few). It‚Äôs a pretty handy trick! No extra JS libraries needed for this async load.
However, there‚Äôs a small resiliency issue. If JS is disabled, the CSS won‚Äôt load.

I know, I know, the number of people who intentionally disable JS is very small. But counterpoint: the solution I‚Äôm recommending here is also super easy to implement! In most cases, it‚Äôd take less than 30 seconds to add. To make sure your CSS loads even with JS disabled, add another link to your stylesheet inside a <noscript> tag.

There you go! Maybe no one will actually need that noscript copy, but it‚Äôs very easy to add and it makes sure that the inline JS solution Scott recommended is truly a progressive enhancement, no side effects.

entry.title: Animating Background Gradients to Make Your PWA More Native

content.p: Read my article ‚ÄúAnimating Background Gradients to Make Your PWA More Native‚Äù at DockYard.com.

When most people think about mentoring, they picture someone more experienced investing time in a close relationship with someone less experienced. Maybe you thought about someone who‚Äôd done that for you - a co-worker, parent, or teacher. In my web development career, I‚Äôve had a different kind of mentoring experience than that standard one. Instead of having an experienced developer invest lots of time in me and my career, I‚Äôve benefited from little bits of help from lots of people over the years. I like to call this ‚Äúdistributed‚Äù mentorship: remote learning from people around the world.

About 10 years ago, I got started in web development as a hobby. I was in grad school (studying an entirely unrelated field) and managed to have ‚Äúfree time‚Äù one semester. My dad had built a few sites back in the 90s and I liked computers so I thought it would be fun to learn how to build a site. My roommate was studying computer science and I asked him how to build a site. He was working on software development, so he just laughed and showed me w3schools. (Yeah, I know NOW not to go there, but hey, I learned a few things from it back then!) I got more direction from a friend David (who was a sysadmin). He wasn‚Äôt an ‚Äúexpert‚Äù at front-end development, but he was more familiar with it. He gave me a piece of fantastic advice: ‚Äúmost websites are built with tables, but CSS is the new thing that cutting-edge sites are using, so start there and forget tables.‚Äù

I remember the new things back then: learning HTML, figuring out that PHP let me have variables and logic, installing IIS & then Apache on my XP laptop, exploring CSS, being mystified that Chrome and Firefox had different default margins on text elements. Most of those ups & downs were part of the standard learning curve for front-end devs back then. Through this time, I didn‚Äôt really have a ‚Äúmentor‚Äù like we usually think of them. David and I had plenty more conversations - he ended up being my hosting service for years and I learned a lot from him. I remember sitting across the table from him at a bagel place while he drew DNS / hosting diagrams on a napkin. I still really enjoy digging into server admin stuff so I‚Äôm grateful for what I learned from him.

Within a year or so of getting experienced with front-end dev, I realized people would probably pay me money for this ‚Äúhobby.‚Äù So I started telling friends what I could do and built a few small paid sites on the side.

After I graduated I got a job maintaining a website for a small non-profit (and running activities for their events every month and a host of other things: it was very much an ‚Äúeveryone helps with everything‚Äù kind of organization). I was given a privately developed CMS with no documentation and little to no positive help from the guy who‚Äôd built it. I learned a lot that year, but it was more visual design from the organization‚Äôs graphic design team - I was pretty isolated as the only ‚Äúweb person.‚Äù A year later, I moved on having learned very little: a bit of JavaScript and ‚Äúnever try to edit an undocumented code base.‚Äù

After that, I moved back to my college town for more grad school (nope, still not studying dev/tech ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø) and got a job as a graduate assistant running a ZenCart site. I‚Äôd been getting more familiar with PHP by using WordPress so that much of the code wasn‚Äôt too difficult. What was more challenging was the dozen or so custom MySQL queries I used to handle reporting every quarter. The site was a small MP3 store, so we reported sales to the original artists and paid their licensing fees to the license holders on any tracks they covered from another artist. The worst queries took up more than a page in Word (yep, that‚Äôs where everything was stored when I arrived). Since then, I‚Äôve forgotten most of that, but that was also a great year for me - I sold my first few Wordpress sites to some clients and settled solidly on WP as a starting point for client work. There were some fun customizations: mp3 storage & playback (before MediaElement.JS was part of WP) and PayPal integration (price & SKU custom fields, no plugins), but nothing that I‚Äôd consider ‚Äúadvanced‚Äù today.

During this time, I didn‚Äôt have a ‚Äúmentor‚Äù per se. I learned a lot from the developer who handed off that ZenCart installation to me - he was kind enough to stay close for support questions for a few months. By now, though, I was relying on a growing network of distributed mentors: devs I followed on Twitter and trustworthy publisher. I‚Äôd become an avid follower of CSS-Tricks, A List Apart, and Smashing Mag. I didn‚Äôt personally meet people like Chris Coyier, Eric Meyer, Jeffrey Zeldman, Andrew Clarke, or Vitaly Freidman, but I read their posts & books and ‚Äúgot mentored‚Äù by them from a distance.

During this time I started to realize that not every mentorship is an in-person relationship over a long period of time. There are times I‚Äôve looked back and wondered, ‚Äúwho was my mentor during this phase?‚Äù and come up blank - until I stop to remember how much I owe to the developers who write and publish and share their knowledge across the web.

A few more years of freelance work went by while I finished up that degree. Then after graduating again, I got hired at my first real developer job. Not ‚Äúa small part of my workload‚Äù development or ‚Äúpart-time for a college,‚Äù but real-live, full-time, development-only work.

By this time, Ethan Marcotte and his magical media queries had changed my CSS world, and shortly into this job, I swallowed my pride (‚Äúbut my CSS is good enough already!‚Äù) and learned Sass. I got pretty proficient at jQuery and was picking up bits of the plain JS that lived beneath it. I was cranking out custom WordPress themes every month or so and loving it. I was the only developer there (it was a small agency), so there wasn‚Äôt much ‚Äúin-person‚Äù mentoring. However that year I got to attend CSSDevConf (my first dev conference!) and came away amazed. I got to meet some of the devs who had been my ‚Äúpublishing mentors‚Äù to that point (hey, Chris & Estelle!) and I met several more devs whose work I started following & learning from immediately (lookin‚Äô at you, Rachel, Micah, & Winston). I discovered CSS animation that weekend and immediately started adding pizzazz to the sites I was working on.

Conference mentors are another useful kind of distributed mentor too. I didn‚Äôt know them at all before then, but Micah Godbolt and Winston Hearn took time to answer my questions about their talks. I got to sit by Chris Coyier, Tab Atkins, and Estelle Weyl one meal, and chat with Jonathan Snook over appetizers one evening. These brief interactions may not seem like very much on their own, but for me, they were really powerful. To realize that these experts were normal people who provide helpful advice and have friendly conversations with a newbie developer was tremendously encouraging.

I‚Äôve talked to a lot of developers whose careers have started similarly: learn/freelance, take a real job, then learn so much in your first year that your next job is a massive jump up. That‚Äôs what happened. I got an offer to join a team of a dozen developers at a larger agency. This was my first experience working with a significant in-person team. It was exciting to see how our individual strengths and weaknesses quickly moved us into collaborative mentorships. I inherited several bloated CSS-framework-based sites and helped the team move forward into lighter, more customizable Sass workflows. I learned the basics of Angular and Ember from devs with more JS experience than I had.

A year later, I took a job with a remote company. The challenges of learning remote work were balanced by a lot of positives: the team had an established workflow, people were already communicating well in Slack & the PM app, and the dev team was internal (so we worked with our own marketing and design departments, instead of reporting to external clients). The same collaborative pattern was at work there too: we had a dev who was our PHP expert, one who was the JS expert, one who knew the company history and business model well, and a CSS/Sass expert (me). We learned from each other well. Again, it didn‚Äôt feel like ‚Äútraditional‚Äù mentorship. Depending on the topic and context, each of us played the role of mentor or mentee at one time or another. And again, since the whole team was remote, this was another form of distributed mentorship. It was a fantastic team to be part of for 2 years.

This spring, I shifted positions again: it took a few months for things to settle, but I‚Äôm a contractor/consultant right now. I‚Äôve been working as a team lead with a company that manages a flexible crew of contractors for web/software development and that‚Äôs been exciting. Having great onboarding/training conversations, constructive code reviews, and teaching moments with junior and intermediate developers has been enjoyable and fulfilling. I‚Äôm currently working with a friend to build a company that incorporates both top-notch web app development and training / apprenticeship opportunities for new devs.

I‚Äôve benefited a lot from ‚Äúdistributed mentoring.‚Äù Twitter people, online publishers, conference speakers & friends, co-workers and peers - they‚Äôve all played important roles in my career, even though it hasn‚Äôt looked like a stereotypical mentorship.

If you‚Äôre starting your journey as a developer, start building a good network of people whose tweets/posts/blogs/work you can follow online and learn from remotely. Also, it can be a tough investment to swing, but attending conferences is a huge help, especially in your first couple years of ‚Äúfull-time‚Äù development work.

If you‚Äôve gotten enough experience to start specializing in a particular language, stack, or framework, use that expertise to grow collaboratively with others. Don‚Äôt get stuck behind fear that you‚Äôre ‚Äúnot expert enough yet‚Äù - if you know just a couple things that a friend or peer doesn‚Äôt, you can help them along. And of course, stay friends with people who know at least a little more than you about some topics so they can help you along.
